title: Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge
text:
The Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge is part of the United States <a href="National%20Wildlife%20Refuge">National Wildlife Refuge</a> (NWR) System, located along a twenty-mile (30 km) section of coastline from <a href="Melbourne%20Beach%2C%20Florida">Melbourne Beach</a> to <a href="Wabasso%20Beach%2C%20Florida">Wabasso Beach, Florida</a>, along <a href="Florida%20State%20Road%20A1A">State Road A1A</a>. The 900 acre (3.6 km2) refuge was established in 1991, to protect the <a href="loggerhead%20sea%20turtle">loggerhead</a> and <a href="green%20turtle">green</a> <a href="sea%20turtle">sea turtle</a>s.
Management.
Since 2012 the Archie Carr NWR is administered as part of the "Everglades Headwaters NWR Complex", along with <a href="Pelican%20Island%20NWR">Pelican Island NWR</a>, <a href="Lake%20Wales%20Ridge%20NWR">Lake Wales Ridge NWR</a>, and the <a href="Everglades%20Headwaters%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge%20and%20Conservation%20Area">Everglades Headwaters National Wildlife Refuge and Conservation Area</a>, through a partnership with the <a href="Caribbean%20Conservation%20Corporation">Caribbean Conservation Corporation</a> (a nonprofit turtle conservation group founded by Dr. <a href="Archie%20Carr">Archie Carr</a> himself) and Archie Carr Working Group.
Habitat.
The refuge provides nesting habitats for approximately one-fourth of all sea turtles nesting in the United States. About 15,000-20,000 sea turtles nests are laid annually, mostly loggerheads, green sea turtles, and some <a href="Leatherback%20turtle">leatherbacks</a>. The refuge also provides habitat for several other threatened and endangered species.
Three centers within the sanctuary are run by <a href="Brevard%20County%2C%20Florida">Brevard County</a> under the aegis of the restrictions established by the federal government.
Conservation efforts.
Archie Carr NWR is threatened by <a href="sea%20level%20rise">sea level rise</a>. Scientists and researchers are studying the impacts of sea level rise on this ecosystem.
